content.webTitle: Jamestown review – new settlers make a splash in Virginia

fields.headline: Jamestown review – new settlers make a splash in Virginia
fields.bodyText: So where were we then, in Jamestown, now starting its second series (Sky1)? Still in early 17th-century Virginia, with the first English settlers. Alice and Verity are taking a stroll inland into the New World. Both are hitched now, and Alice is heavily pregnant. Verity would like to be too, but her useless husband is a drunk and can’t live up to his name: Meredith Rutter. Alice slips, she tumbles, screaming, down the bank and into the river, where she has an impromptu water-birth and delivers Jamestown’s first-ever boy. You don’t see that on One Born Every Minute. And he’s helped into the world by Maria, an enslaved midwife. Yes, I’m afraid there’s slavery here now; the slaves are picking the colonists’ Golden Virginia for them. It’s one in, one out, though, because here’s Samuel, Jocelyn’s fella, dead on the river bank, a vulture having a little peck at one of his eyes. Was it the indigenous people who killed him? Perhaps. Relations with them seem to have soured since the last season. Not that Jocelyn seems at all bothered by her loss – until she finds out that losing her husband means losing her house and everything else as well. “Without a husband, a woman simply has no position in Virginia,” Temperance, the governor’s wife, tells her. Girl power hasn’t broken America yet … Hold up though, Jocelyn’s not going to take this lying down. “Sir, you may cut me down,” she hisses to the tobacco company man. “But not so low that my nails cannot reach your eyes.” Ouch, you have to be careful of your eyes around here, what with the vultures and with Jocelyn. Pedro, another of Jamestown’s enslaved inhabitants, is getting a bit cocky too. I think it’s a race between him and Jocelyn as to who ends up running the place. Maybe both. Jamestown shouldn’t be taken too seriously. Nor as a history lesson. Don’t be fooled by the authentic brutality and dirt, or by any accuracy there might be in the events, stuff that actually happened. Look at the storylines and the attitudes, and what you see is modern-day soap opera dressed in period costume with a sailing ship parked up at the quay. Once you accept that, it’s actually quite fun.
